TAXONOMIC CLASS.content: TAXONOMIC CLASS: Fine-loamy, mixed, superactive, frigid Calcic Argixerolls

TYPICAL PEDON.content:
TYPICAL PEDON:  Border gravelly clay loam.
1--0 to 8 inches; brownish-gray or weak-brown gravelly clay loam, the gravel mainly subangular fragments of sandstone.  Range in thickness about 8".
2--8 to 18 inches; medium-brown, moderately compact gravelly clay loam.  Range in thickness about 10".
3--18 inches +; similar colored compact gravelly clay loam with moderate brown cast, becoming more stony with depth.

TYPE LOCATION.content: TYPE LOCATION:  On state line about 1 mile north of Border, Bear Lake County, Idaho.

RANGE IN CHARACTERISTICS.content: RANGE IN CHARACTERISTICS:  The content of gravel varies.  In places where limestone fragments occur the subsoil is somewhat calcareous.  The profile varies somewhat with the character of the included gravel.  The substratum below 3 feet may contain very little fine material.

DRAINAGE AND PERMEABILITY.content: GEOGRAPHIC SETTING:  Gently sloping alluvial fans, footslopes, and terraces.  Frequently the soils lie at the outlets of canyons issuing from areas of sandstone.

DISTRIBUTION AND EXTENT.content: DRAINAGE AND PERMEABILITY:  Good to excessive.

REGIONAL OFFICE.content: USE AND VEGETATION:  Areas in Idaho are used with indifferent results for dryland wheat and alfalfa.  A somewhat greater acreage along the border in Wyoming is in native grass pasture.  Grass and sagebrush.

ORIGIN.content: DISTRIBUTION AND EXTENT:  Southeastern Idaho and western Wyoming.

REMARKS.section: MLRA SOIL SURVEY REGIONAL OFFICE (MO) RESPONSIBLE
REMARKS.content: MLRA SOIL SURVEY REGIONAL OFFICE (MO) RESPONSIBLE: Bozeman, Montana
